newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's real drops 0.12 pct on dollar outflows.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's real drops 0.12 pct on dollar outflows.

text.p: Brazil's real fell 0.12 percent to close at 1.0740 per dollar on dollar outflows in the commercial foreign exchange market and a decline in the real-dollar mini-band, dealers said.
At 1650 local/1950 GMT, preliminary figures for commercial and financial forex contracts showed a $40 million deficit.
In the late afternoon, the Central Bank sold dollars at 1.0740 reais per greenback to give liquidity to the market.

Two other factors were cited by dealers to explain the real's fall. First, the Central Bank lowered the mini-band 0.09 percent to between 1.0690 and 1.0740 reais per dollar through a buy/sell auction.

The previous mini-band was set on May 20 at between 1.0680 and 1.0730 per greenback. So far this month, the mini-band has fallen 0.52 percent against the dollar compared to an average drop of between 0.57 and 0.61 percent in the past four months.
Dealers also speculated that the real currency was pressured by banks maintaining long positions in the spot market to arbitrage in the dollar futures market.
In the interbank floating rate market, the real closed at 1.0736 per dollar, down 0.04 percent. In the parallel market, the real ended flat at 1.130 per dollar.
